subject: RE: [junit] Re: Help plz...
msgSnippet: ... OK, I now have two programs.  The original is NameLength.  The other is identical, except that the blocks of code timing long and short have been reversed
messageBody:
On Thu, 25 Sep 2003, Ilja Preuss wrote:

> > The long names ran
> > consistently faster in the Java tests. Since the test runs in
> > a continuous loop, this can't be the result of any startup effect.
>
> It can still be a result of sequence. I have seen the strangest effects
> in Java benchmarks...

OK, I now have two programs. The original is NameLength. The other
is identical, except that the blocks of code timing long and short
have been reversed (long precedes short). Call these NL and NL2.
In repeated tests (4 NL loops, 4 NL2, 4 NL, 4 NL2, ...) I get

NL
short 11.9s 12.0s 11.9s 12.0s 12.0s
long 12.1s 12.1s 12.0s 12.0s 12.0s

NL2
short 11.9s 12.1s 11.9s 11.9s 12.2s
long 13.2s 13.0s 13.2s 13.1s 13.0s

That is, the short-name results are pretty much identical either way,
but the long-name results are definitely slower if they are done _before_
the short names in the for loop.

Long names are about 1% slower in the original NL program, but drift
around, with longer names occasionally faster. Longer names are
consistently and significantly slower when running NL2, about 9-10%.

FWIW inspection of the bytecode generated shows no significant
differences between the two loops

What does 'the result of sequence' mean?

--
